column1:
After a weeks-long journey that began in the unnerving chaos at the Kabul airport::: a Purdue language and culture instructor helped four family members relocate from Afghanistan to West Lafayette.

The family was among the thousands of Afghan refugees who fled the country in August when the Taliban returned to power.

They left behind family::: homes and all of their belongings when they fled their home country::: but members of the Purdue community are helping them start over in the U.S.

https://purdue.university/31bRA1M

PURDUE.EDU
After harrowing escape from Afghanistan::: Purdue instructor brings her family to West Lafayette

New #Purdue-developed drug designed to help surgeons find cancer tumors and cells has been approved by U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Cytalux::: invented by Purdue University College of Science professor Philip Low::: is the first tumor-targeted fluorescent marker for ovarian cancer to be FDA-approved. Purdue Center for Cancer Research

Enjoying some Stove Top Stuffing for #Thanksgiving this year? 🦃

You can thank #PurdueUniversity alumna Ruth Siems::: a 1953 home economics graduate credited with the invention of Stove Top stuffing. The product hit shelves in 1971 and quickly became a Thanksgiving staple. https://purdue.university/2Hu7L0S

column1:
Giant leaps are happening here.

Purdue Polytechnic High School - South Bend provides a tuition-free::: student-first education that breaks the mold of the traditional high school experience.

Discover PPHS South Bend: https://purdue.university/3FIKO2J

Purdue reinvented the high school experience by creating Purdue Polytechnic HS. How? By allowing its students to reinvent themselves.

Follow three PPHS graduates – Prem::: Audrey and Keante – as you watch “PPHS First Class:::” a documentary series about the first-ever graduating class of PPHS. You’ll watch them encounter challenges and face them head on. You’ll watch them learn to communicate and collaborate. And most of all::: you’ll watch them grow into true Boilermakers.

Available now on YouTube. https://purdue.university/Keante
column3: I've been very impressed with what I've read about Purdue Polytechnic ...I believe the grads will make a difference in the world.

column1:
Looking for an interesting conversation starter this #Thanksgiving? 🦃

We’re sharing a new update from our #ThisIsPurdue ultra-white paint episode with Prof. Xiulin Ruan::: professor of mechanical engineering at #Purdue. In an effort to curb global warming::: Xiulin and his team created the whitest white acrylic paint. And now::: the paint has a Guinness World Records title and appears in the 2022 Guinness World Records book. Listen in as we share more about one of our most popular episodes to date!

column1:
When Rich Dionne::: associate professor of practice in theatre::: saw the incredible need for theatre engineering education::: he joined Mary Pilotte::: associate professor of engineering practice::: to create Fusion Studio for Entertainment and Engineering::: a hub dedicated to sharing ideas and building connections in the live entertainment engineering industry.

As the only school in the country offering a theatre engineering degree::: Purdue is uniquely positioned to fill the need for education surrounding the rapidly advancing technology in TV::: film::: theme parks::: live events and theatre.

Learn more about Fusion Studio: https://purdue.university/3nA6NlS

PURDUE.EDU
Bringing a STEM approach to live entertainment

column1: The Memorial Fountain was donated by the class of 1894 and was dedicated in 1895::: only 26 years after Purdue was founded. At one point::: Purdue Animal Sciences kept the fountain stocked with fish. Located across from University Hall next to the grave of John Purdue::: the fountain stands in its original place as a testament to #Boilermaker legacy.
column3: Outstanding. Thanks for info
column4: One of my favorite spots on campus to sit and read between classes. I stopped by briefly on my way through Indiana in the spring and couldn't resist a photo of my puppy near there.
column5: One of her sister fountains is in my local park in Chicago. I think about Old Purdue every time I pass it.
column6: I love this fountain. I used to sit on a bench near the fountain when I was at Purdue. Very peaceful.
column7: Never realized it was so old! There needs to be more posts like this.
column8: As a history major::: many of my classes were in University Hall and I always sat by the fountain or met people there. Good memories.
column9:

engraved somewhere nearby? He mentioned “Boy::: it sure has not held up very well.” I had to tell him ‘95 meant 1895 NOT 1995 😜

Who’s ready to get loud this season? 📣

Built in 1967::: Guy J. Mackey Arena is widely considered one of the loudest arenas in the U.S.::: thanks to the domed aluminum roof and the thousands of persistent #Boilermaker fans that fill the seats during every game.

column4: My father and I attended the open house in 1967. We got to see the locker rooms::: workout rooms::: etc. I went to some games in 1967 and 68. I remember seeing Rick Mount play. I was a Purdue student from 1969 - 1973 and went to some games. My parents knew Red Mackey.
column5: Attended games 1969-1973. I remember Rick Mount and great teams. No 3 point line or shot clock. I still love college basketball.
column6:

column1: Since their invention::: flight simulators have been used to safely prepare pilots for flight. This photo from the late 1950s shows a #Purdue student and instructor using a Link Trainer::: a flight simulator developed by Indiana native Ed Link in 1929. Now::: Purdue University Aviation Technology students have access to a Hawker 900XP full-motion simulator as well as Airbus A320 and Boeing 737 flight simulators. Purdue is one of only a handful of universities in the U.S. that have access to this level of technology.

column10: Funny Story.....I worked in the press box in the early 80’s serving soft drinks on the 3rd level for Vans Catering::: who at that time catered the whole press box. I was able to watch some of the games for the most part and when I couldn’t watch I obviously was listening to the PA announcer. For several years I heard this announcer say “Someone on the tackle”...... I would think to myself::: this guy needs to know who the players are......fast forward to 84 and I’m looking through the program and the roster.....low and behold I come across LB Kevin “Sumlin” and it hit me😂😂😂😂😂. “Sumlin on the tackle” 🤭

Purdue alum Joseph Pabst grew up in Managua::: Nicaragua::: in a home that emphasized education::: self-improvement and persistence. After graduating from Purdue in 2000 with a degree in aviation technology::: Pabst went on to make his family proud as an innovator in the airline industry.

Pabst and his family visited Purdue’s campus in 2019::: and he was happy to see the growth of the Purdue University Latino Cultural Center.

“Today’s students are very fortunate to have a Latino Cultural Center as a home away from home:::” he says. “I hope they will continue to network with each other and with students of all backgrounds. I encourage them to embrace change and learn about the differences that make us each unique.”

Read Pabst’s story and others in celebration of National #HispanicHeritageMonth: https://purdue.university/3jrvRcr

column1:
“When you are in the classroom learning together::: it goes beyond your skin color. When you walk out of that room after taking the same exam::: you realize that you are equals. You can learn and develop together. You can’t let anybody ever take that away from you.”

--Adrienne White-Faines::: daughter of Winifred Parker White

Adrienne’s mother Winifred Parker White understood this message at her core back in 1946 when she and her sister Frieda Parker led the successful campaign to integrate Purdue student housing. Winifred and Frieda were civil rights trailblazers::: and their commitment to standing up for what was right makes them Boilermakers in every sense of the word.

Meet the Parker Sisters: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_S3RrbFgRuA

column1: Initially dedicated in 1904::: the Stone Lions Fountain still sits in its original location outside of Stanley Coulter Hall at #Purdue. The fountain stopped running water beginning around the time this photo was taken in 1929. No documentation exists to tell us why the water was turned off. Today the fountain is once again a functioning drinking fountain thanks to the Purdue Reamer Club::: who worked to bring the fountain back to its original purpose in 2001.

When Frieda and Winifred Parker enrolled at Purdue in 1946::: they could not live on campus. The two sisters and their family led the successful campaign to integrate university housing.

On October 3::: Purdue held a dedication ceremony for the newly named Frieda and Winifred Parker Residence Halls to honor their commitment to the fight for equity and access in education.

Watch the documentary about the Parker sisters’ story and the Parker Halls dedication here: https://purdue.university/3AAQsRl
column3: What an amazing testament for positive change - there should never be a barrier due to the color of a person’s skin. We still have a long way to go though. It will not happen in my life span::: but I am hopeful eventually we will all realize and act upon the fact we are here to help and love one another collectively. The world has will be a much better place as a result.

column1:
Val Schull::: PhD agricultural and biological engineering ’21::: left their mark on the Purdue University Latino Cultural Center by combining their passions for sustainable farming and food justice to create Jardin Semillas::: an on-campus community garden.

The garden serves as a hands-on educational experience for students to learn about food production::: sustainable irrigation::: and what it means to have access to culturally-important foods.

Val says they always looked forward to National Latinx/e Heritage Month celebrations at the LCC. “As a queer and nonbinary Latinx person::: it has been great to see the LCC collaborate with the cultural centers on campus to bring programs that demonstrate how the Latinx/e community is not a monolith.”

Learn more about Val’s contribution to the LCC here: https://purdue.university/3BJ9RRi

This is huge! When I was there in 2017 (Nutriton and Dietetics) we had a small garden ran by Lauren Link that was intended for the student athletes. It’s really cool to see this idea expand to all of the students!

The school’s mission is to reinvent the high school experience through STEM-focused::: hands-on learning and to offer its students a path to Purdue. PPHS has created new opportunities for Hoosier students who are underserved by traditional high schools and underrepresented in higher education.

column1: It was a historic day at #PurdueUniversity as we named the Frieda and Winifred Parker Residence Halls in honor of the Parker sisters who integrated our dorms in 1947::: two of the first African-American women to live on campus. https://purdue.university/3vvMIhE
column3:
A little more information from Frieda's obit: "In 1950::: Frieda graduated from Purdue University with a B.S. in Home Economics. Frieda immediately went into teaching. Frieda's entire career was in education. Following a temporary placement in Tucson::: Arizona::: Frieda embarked on a teaching career in Milwaukee::: Wisconsin::: where she was one of the founding organizers of the Teachers Union in the Milwaukee Public School System. Frieda worked for more than 50 years in the Milwaukee Public Schools::: the Milwaukee Area Technical College::: V.E Carter Development Center::: and various other community entities. In addition to teaching high school students::: Frieda supervised student teachers::: coordinated child development and day care programs::: as well as created and implemented "School to Work" programs for the Milwaukee Public Schools.

Frieda has always generously shared her talents with family and friends; there is no way to recount here the full extent of Frieda's decades of contributions to her community and the positive impact she has made on those with whom she has come into contact. After officially retiring from education::: Frieda remained active in several community and national organizations including the NAACP::: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority::: the Milwaukee Links::: Jack and Jill and the Purdue University Black Alumni Association. Frieda was also a founding member of Central United Methodist Church on Wisconsin Avenue."

Did you know Purdue offers a 15-credit minor in Latin American and Latino Studies? Open to students from all colleges and majors::: this minor complements a wide range of academic and professional goals.

Professor Alfred López::: leader of the program::: says::: “Our goal is to provide a level of cultural literacy — what it means to be Latinx — to be able to function in a multi-cultural world::: whether that be in a workplace like Chicago or Los Angeles::: or as far as Ecuador or Brazil.”

Learn more about Professor López and the Latin American and Latino Studies minor here: https://purdue.university/3ipu9I7

column1:
#PurdueUniversity is naming the ground floor of the Purdue Memorial Union for the family of Bob and Judy Atlas in recognition of a $2.5 million gift from the Robert and Judith Atlas Family Foundation.

The ground floor of the Purdue Memorial Union will be known as the Atlas Family Marketplace. The transformed space will preserve and highlight the history of the campus landmark::: which opened in 1924.

The Atlas Family Marketplace will include:
• Eleven new dining venues::: including a sports bar owned by Purdue alumnus Drew Brees.
• Two outdoor-seating terraces with fire pits; improved convenience store.
• Four performance stages: three inside::: one outside.
• Added fireplace lounge with exterior light wells.
https://purdue.university/39Yirzq

PURDUE.EDU
$2.5 million gift names Purdue Memorial Union ground floor

During #PurdueHomecoming week::: we recognize Kassandra Agee Chandler::: #Purdue's first Black homecoming queen::: elected in 1978. Agee Chandler drew upon the strength of her faith::: family::: friends::: and dorm-mates to persistently pursue her campaign.

As a leader on campus::: she was a member of Alpha Lambda Delta honor society::: Purdue Pals::: the Black Voices of Inspiration Choir::: and a founding member of Purdue’s Society of Minority Managers. She served as a counselor for the Business Opportunity Program and was a member of Mortar Board. https://purdue.university/2ZyGArm

column1:
Check out a #Purdue record for the whitest paint in the latest edition of “Guinness World Records.” https://purdue.university/3hEe3de

And make sure to listen to #ThisIsPurdue where we hear professor Xiulin Ruan speak about the persistent pursuit of creating the whitest white paint. https://purdue.university/2TCCAXz
column3:
Breaking a world record wasn’t the goal of the researchers::: Curbing global warming was.
“When we started this project about seven years ago::: we had saving energy and fighting climate change in mind:::” said Xiulin Ruan::: the professor of mechanical engineering at Purdue::: said in a statement. The idea was to make a paint that would reflect sunlight away from a buildings. Making this paint really reflective::: however::: also made it really white. The paint reflects 98.1% of solar radiation while also emitting infrared heat.

Using this new paint to cover a roof area of about 1:::000 square feet could result in a cooling power of 10 kilowatts. “That’s more powerful than the air conditioners used by most houses:::” Ruan said.

Typical commercial white paint gets warmer rather than cooler. Paints on the market that are designed to reject heat reflect only 80% to 90% of sunlight and can’t make surfaces cooler than their surroundings.
column4:
One does need ground to be hot so that air is heated from below to cause convection and reduce air pollution::: create convectional rain::: etc. But this invention could allow for massive water-efficient
greenhouses in deserts. When dry air is cooled the relative humidity increases and the vapour pressure deficit improves so that plants can grow better. The cool white paint could reduce air temperatures in greenhouses in the United Arab Emirates::: etc. With a little evaporative cooling in the greenhouse with white walls food could be grown cheaply. The vapour pressure deficit should usually be less than about 1.2 kPa and this white paint could help a lot.

Example: Desert air has air temperature of 45 deg C with relative humidity of 15% and atmospheric pressure is 100 kPa.
This air is cooled in the white greenhouse to 35 deg C and therefore the relative humidity becomes 25.572%.
If the greenhouse has volume of 1000 cubic metres and 4.51 kg of water is evaporated for evaporative cooling the final temperature will be 25.50 deg C. This represents evaporative cooling of efficiency of 65.70% (65.70% of the way down to the wet bulb temperature).
The final relative humidity is then 63.34% and the vapour pressure deficit has fallen from 4.188 kPa just before evaporative cooling to 1.196 kPa::: which is suitable.

column1:
On the morning of Sept. 11::: 2001::: Purdue alumna Heather Penney took off in an unarmed F-16 fighter plane intending to crash into the hijacked United Flight 93 and prevent it from reaching Washington::: D.C. She did not reach the airliner in time to sacrifice her own life::: but the flight’s passengers did so when they fought back against the terrorists::: forcing the plane down in the Pennsylvania countryside.

Penney frequently relives that day’s tragic events in public speaking engagements. By spotlighting the heroism of the everyday Americans on Flight 93 who undermined the hijackers::: saving their nation from further devastation::: Penney encourages audiences to honor the passengers’ legacy by being their better selves every day.

Read Penney’s story at: https://purdue.university/3tsKoIM

PURDUE.EDU
Fighter pilot::: a Purdue alumna::: was prepared to sacrifice her life on 9/11

column11:
If there's one thing I have learned in my life::: it is that science changes. The data we originally observed in regards to vaccine effectiveness was mostly related to the first (alpha) COVID-19 virus. But sadly::: because so many are choosing their individual freedom over an entire nation getting back to normal::: we have allowed the virus to mutate::: putting us back at square one. As a student at Purdue::: I'm glad our leaders listen to the science::: even if its not always what we want to hear. I'll be really upset::: and I know others will be too::: if we don't get to have a senior year full of concerts::: football games::: and outings within our clubs and friend groups because of the unvaccinated. I simply do not understand the issue with getting vaccinated. I can understand not doing it for medical and religious reasons::: but we've had vaccine requirements all the way through elementary school::: middle school::: high school::: and even in college! This one is no different.

I am PROUD to be a Boilermaker!

column52:
A friend of mine had a conversation with the CDC about the Wuhan virus and it's experimental vaccinations. It's enlightening:
ME: CDC::: should I get poked if I already had Covid?
CDC: “Yes::: you should be poked regardless of whether you already had COVID-19. That’s because experts do not yet know how long you are protected from getting sick again after recovering from COVID-19.”
ME: Oh::: okay::: we don’t know how long natural immunity lasts. Got it. So::: how long does poke-induced immunity last?
CDC: “There is still a lot we are learning about COVID-19 pokes and CDC is constantly reviewing evidence and updating guidance. We don’t know how long protection lasts for those who are poked.”
ME: Okay … but wait a second. I thought you said the reason I need the poke was because we don’t know how long my natural immunity lasts::: but it seems like you’re saying we ALSO don’t know how long poke immunity lasts either. So::: how exactly is the poke immunity better than my natural immunity?
CDC: …
ME: Uh … alright. But::: haven’t there been a bunch of studies suggesting that natural immunity could last for years or decades?
CDC: Yes.
NEWYORKTIMES: “Years::: maybe even decades::: according to a new study.”
ME: Ah. So natural immunity might last longer than poke immunity?
CDC: Possibly. You never know.
ME: Okay. If I get the poke::: does that mean I won’t get sick?
BRITAIN: Nope. We are just now entering a seasonal spike and about half of our infections and hospital admissions are poked people.
ME: CDC::: is this true? Are there a lot of people in the U.S. catching Covid after getting the poke?
CDC: We stopped tracking breakthrough cases. We accept voluntary reports of breakthroughs but aren’t out there looking for them.
ME: Does that mean that if someone comes in the hospital with Covid::: you don’t track them because they’ve been poked? You only track the UN-poked Covid cases?
CDC: That’s right.
ME: Oh::: okay. Hmm. Well::: if I can still get sick after I get the poke::: how is it helping me?
CDC: We never said you wouldn’t get sick. We said it would reduce your chances of serious illness or death.
ME: Oh::: sorry. Alright::: exactly how much does it reduce my chance of serious illness or death.
CDC: We don’t know “exactly.”
ME: Oh. Then what’s your best estimate for how much risk reduction there is?
CDC: We don’t know::: okay? Next question.
ME: Um::: if I’m healthy and don’t want the poke::: is there any reason I should get it?
CDC: Yes::: for the collective.
ME: How does the collective benefit from me getting poked?
CDC: Because you could spread the virus to someone else who might get sick and die.
ME: Can a poked person spread the virus to someone else?
CDC: Yes.
ME: So if I get poked::: I could still spread the virus to someone else?
CDC: Yes.
ME: But I thought you just said::: the REASON I should get poked was to prevent me spreading the virus? How does that make sense if I can still catch Covid and spread it after getting the poke?
CDC: Never mind that. The other thing is::: if you stay unpoked::: there’s a chance the virus could possibly mutate into a strain that escapes the pokes protection::: putting all poked people at risk.
ME: So the poke stops the virus from mutating?
CDC: No.
ME: So it can still mutate in poked people?
CDC: Yes.
ME: This seems confusing. If the poke doesn’t stop mutations::: and it doesn’t stop infections::: then how does me getting poked help prevent a more deadly strain from evolving to escape the poke?
CDC: You aren’t listening::: okay? The bottom line is: as long as you are unpoked::: you pose a threat to poked people.
ME: But what KIND of threat??
CDC: The threat that they could get a serious case of Covid and possibly die.
ME: My brain hurts. Didn’t you JUST say that the poke doesn’t keep people from catching Covid::: but prevents a serious case or dying? Now it seems like you’re saying poked people can still easily die from Covid even after they got the poke just by running into an unpoked person! Which is it??
CDC: That’s it::: we’re hanging up now.
ME: Wait! I just want to make sure I understand all this. So::: even if I ALREADY had Covid::: I should STILL get poked::: because we don’t know how long natural immunity lasts::: and we also don’t know how long poke immunity lasts. And I should get the poke to keep a poked person from catching Covid from me::: but even if I get the poke::: I can give it to the poked person anyways. And::: the other poked person can still easily catch a serious case of Covid from me and die. Do I have all that right?
…
ME: Um::: hello? Is anyone there?

What’s the PurdueDataMine really all about?

From April 2020:

“The next frontier for university technology transfer will likely be in the transformation of data-rich sectors using artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning technologies. One area largely accumulating data is the healthcare sector. Medical knowledge is doubling every 73 days::: yet we are barely scratching the surface of utilizing this data. With our computing power today and the new era of AI we are at the cusp of a healthcare revolution. Academic institutions are sitting on massive amounts of valuable data that is vastly underutilized::: and research institutions will soon begin to recognize and develop healthcare data into the next revolutionary asset.”

column11:
Please remove if not allowed. My 13 yr old daughter created a project which gained National publicity last year. She donates draw string bags filled with items for children to police departments. These bags contain toys and other items to help children that have experienced something traumatic and the police officers are trying to help them remain calm. She has received feedback from departments that have used these at homicide scenes::: car accidents::: or if a child is being taken from their home. I wanted to share her site in case anyone might be interested in helping her in funding her project. Although she is currently doing these bags in Indiana only::: her hope is to one day get Smile Bags in squad cars in every state. Please like her Facebook page and share with as many people you can. Thank you.
Miles of Many Smiles

column4:
Purdue is doing some great things to combat the pandemic. I am glad to see that Purdue has dispensed lots of vaccinations and is strongly encouraging all campus community members to get vaccinated.

There is still more that Purdue can do to protect the community.

Problem: Purdue is starting regular surveillance testing (https://
protect.purdue.e
du/updates/
new-tool-launchi
ng-to-track-cam
pus-covid-19-va
ccinations-invi
tation-email-co
ming-soon/) starting Aug 23 however student orientation ( https://
www.purdue.edu/
orientation/bgr/
index.html) starts nearly a week earlier on Aug 17. Students will start to arrive and move into dormitories as early as Aug 14th so there will be no surveillance for the first 9 days when students are present. Also::: “regular surveillance testing” is undefined. An infected Purdue student can come into contact with hundreds of others in the course of a single day.

Solution: Begin surveillance testing as soon as students start to arrive. Test daily.

Problem: Purdue is leaving it to students to find their own quarantine (https://
protect.purdue.e
du/updates/
protect-purdue-f
or-fall-2021/) location if they become sick with Covid-19. This is an unrealistic expectation of an 18 - 19 year old who is away from home (and not feeling well). Too many sick students will likely find it easier to stay in their own accommodations and risk spreading the virus.

Solution: Set aside whatever space is necessary for quarantine so no student is left without a safe space to go to when in need of quarantine.

Problem: Purdue is not allowing dormitory residents to request a roommate based on vaccination status. While the vaccinated student should be safe::: there have been cases of vaccinated individuals (https://
www.cdc.gov/
coronavirus/
2019-ncov/
vaccines/
effectiveness/
why-measure-effe
ctiveness/
breakthrough-cas
es.html) getting sick and we don’t know what future Covid mutations might cause.

Solution: Assign all vaccinated dormitory residents a room with another vaccinated resident. Even better::: put all unvaccinated students in a single dormitory building.

The single best thing that Purdue can do is to join hundreds of other universities and colleges (https://
universitybusine
ss.com/
state-by-state-l
ook-at-colleges
-requiring-vacc
ines/) that are requiring vaccination in order to return to campus.

Did you know #Purdue has been hosting commencement at the iconic Elliott Hall of Music since the 1940s?

In this episode of #ThisIsPurdue::: Lesa Beals::: senior associate registrar::: and Chris Pass::: senior assistant registrar::: share highlights from Purdue’s first outdoor commencement ceremony at Ross-Ade Stadium.

They explain how they teamed up with other #BigTen universities to pull off a ceremony five times larger than normal::: and how they prepared for things out of their control (AKA Indiana weather)!

Plus::: you’ll hear #PurdueUniversity President Mitch Daniels’ full 2021 Spring commencement speech. #PurdueWeDidIt

column1:
If nothing changes::: the world’s oceans will hold more trash than fish by 2050. #Purdue researchers are determined to stop this from happening by solving the plastic waste problem.

A team from Purdue Engineering recently patented a technology called Low-Pressure Hydrothermal Processing::: which is an environmentally safe and economically viable way of turning plastic into fuel. This innovation could lead to less dumping::: more recycling and cleaner oceans. #TheNextGiantLeap

Learn more about Professor Linda Wang and her team’s discoveries here: https://purdue.university/3wDnNKs

PURDUE.EDU
Purdue innovation affordably turning plastics into fuel

Sweden imports and cleanly burns trash to produce electricity. We should be doing the same instead of dumping truck after truck into landfills. Their exhaust aftertreatment systems cleans the pollutants from the escaping gases leaving clean air.

This is probably not nearly as efficient as Nuclear Energy however if people really want to stand behind any kind of Green movement let's start by ending the practice of landfills where possible. Oh and let's cut the practice of mailing junk mail as well...

column1: The locomotive design of #Purdue's official mascot celebrates the University's renowned engineering programs. The first Boilermaker Special was presented in September 1940 and has been used to announce campus events ever since. #NationalMascotDay
column3: The Boilermaker Special is the OFFICIAL Purdue mascot. It is cared for and operated by the Purdue Reamer Club. I am an alumnus of that club and a former BMS Chairman. What an awesome experience. What an awesome mascot.

These smart clothes are powered wirelessly through a flexible::: silk-based coil sewn on the textile. The only downside::: clothes needs to be washed.

column3:
Look I love you Purdue::: but you’re a STEM school. You gotta believe someone is questioning that 1 trillion figure. Let’s ignore first world population stagnation and assume in 9 years the population grows to 8 billion people. That’s 125 unique Internet-facing
devices for every single human on the planet::: infant to end of life elderly::: regardless of the developmental status of the individual’s country or region::: or individual socioeconomic factors. I like to think I’ve got it pretty well off. But I don’t think I could name 125 unique internet-facing
devices I’ve used in the last year. Maybe I have::: but that assumes everyone else has at least that many too.

column1:
"It makes me feel so awesome that we were able to provide the access for them [at PPHS] and then they were able to take it. The students are really geeked about being a Purdue student and that’s a pride moment.”

Our new episode of #ThisIsPurdue features Shatoya Ward::: the founding principal at Purdue Polytechnic HS Englewood. Shatoya discusses how PPHS is reinventing the traditional high school experience::: her excitement for the school’s first graduating class of seniors::: and why we’ve transitioned from the Industrial Age to the Informational Age. [Hint: There’s no longer a right or wrong answer – there's a best answer].

You’ll also hear from Kayla Owens::: senior at #PPHS and future #Boilermaker. Listen in as we celebrate this first graduating class! 🎓

https://purdue.university/2RSfuev

Purdue Polytechnic HS senior Xavier Howard says::: “Through my education at PPHS::: I’ve become much more confident in what I can do. I’ve also become much better at collaborating with others through all the team projects. These are important skills to have for future jobs.”

Who says you have to wait until college to start developing skills that will add value to companies? Through self-directed learning::: PPHS students gain independence and take control of their educations::: pursuing their passions and taking flight. That’s the power of a PPHS education. #ReinventingEducation

Learn more: https://purdue.university/3vsp0Uc

PURDUE.EDU
PPHS fuels creativity::: builds confidence

Effective immediately::: individuals need not wear a mask when outdoors on campus. Previously::: masks were required outdoors if continuous safe social distancing was not possible — although the Purdue community frequently adopted more stringent compliance in practice::: another testament to their steadfast dedication to protecting Purdue.

Until a greater share of the campus community is vaccinated against COVID-19 and has documentation of their vaccination on file with the Protect Purdue Health Center::: wearing a face mask remains required indoors — including in classrooms::: research and instructional laboratories::: in dining halls when not eating and the common spaces of campus buildings. #PurdueUniversity

Lindsay Hamm::: lecturer::: Department of Sociology::: Purdue University College of Liberal Arts::: has been recognized with a 2021 Excellence in Instruction Award for Lecturers. The award honors academic staff with the rank of Lecturer or Senior Lecturer for outstanding undergraduate teaching. #GiantLeaps

"I love the interactional nature of teaching. It's not just me putting a bunch of stuff I know into a lecture or assigning things I find interesting for students to read. It's about coming together from our different social locations and life experiences to help make sense of structural issues and personal troubles."

Subscribe to #ThisIsPurdue wherever you get your podcasts and listen in today.

https://purdue.university/3tInED7

Jennifer Hall::: senior lecturer::: Lamb School of Communication at Purdue University::: Purdue University College of Liberal Arts::: is a 2021 recipient of the Excellence in Instruction Award for Lecturers. The award honors academic staff with the rank of Lecturer or Senior Lecturer for outstanding undergraduate teaching. #GiantLeaps

Hall finds that stepping into her classroom at #Purdue is the most energizing part of her week. "It's an energy - there's so much going on and so much potential::: in both the students and the campus."

Read more: https://purdue.university/3fByRjG

Graduating senior Keenan McKibben on Purdue Polytechnic High School: “Here::: they don’t hold your hand. They give you what you need to grow and then they let you soar.”

Keenan is soaring::: all right. His robotics team won the district competition::: beating out 40 other schools::: during their rookie year. They got to compete on the state and regional level::: too. PPHS helped Keenan take flight::: but it was his dedication and commitment that propelled him and his teammates to the stars.

Learn more about Keenan’s PPHS experience ➡️ https://purdue.university/3v1KHu9

PURDUE.EDU
A suPURDUEper experience

A long time ago::: in a galaxy far far away . . . stars exploded. A #PurdueUniversity astronomy professor is helping his students study the remnants using VR headsets. Purdue Physics and Astronomy::: Purdue University College of Science

Learn more: https://purdue.university/33SlNRJ

#PurdueInnovation

With three locations::: Purdue Polytechnic HS helps students and families prepare for the next chapter of their lives: pathways to college::: lifelong learning::: and careers in advanced manufacturing::: technology and jobs not even envisioned yet.

Learn more: https://purdue.university/3cBgSZ7

#Purdue recognizes Greg Strimel::: assistant professor::: Department of Technology Leadership and Innovation::: Purdue Polytechnic Institute ::: with a 2021 Exceptional Early Career Teaching Award. This award annually recognizes exceptional undergraduate faculty members with the rank of assistant professor. #GiantLeaps

"This award means so much because it comes on the recommendation of students. I want to provide them with an authentic undergraduate learning experience::: where they are involved in real stuff::: doing real projects outside of the classroom. That's my whole point of being at Purdue."

Read more: https://purdue.university/3hGljX3

NOTICE FOR EMPLOYERS::: UNIVERSITIES AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS MANDATING COVID-19 TESTS
April 26::: 2021
This serves as notice that the mandate for any individual to be tested against COVID-19 for employment or participation at a university or other institution violates federal law. All COVID-19 tests::: whether polymerase chain reaction (PCR)::: antigen tests or others::: are authorized::: not approved or licensed::: by the federal government; they are Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) only. They merely “may be effective.” Federal law states:
Title 21 U.S.C. § 360bbb-3(e)(1)(
A)(ii)(I-III) of the Federal Food::: Drug::: and Cosmetic Act states:
individuals to whom the product is administered are informed—
(I) that the Secretary has authorized the emergency use of the product;
(II) of the significant known and potential benefits and risks of such use::: and of the extent to which such benefits and risks are unknown; and
(III) of the option to accept or refuse administration of the product::: of the consequences::: if any::: of refusing administration of the product::: and of the alternatives to the product that are available and of their benefits and risks.
EUA products are by definition experimental and thus require the right to refuse. Under the Nuremberg Code::: the foundation of ethical medicine::: no one may be coerced to participate in a medical experiment. Consent of the individual is “absolutely essential.” A federal court held that even the U.S. military could not mandate EUA vaccines to soldiers. Doe #1 v. Rumsfeld::: 297 F.Supp.2d 119 (2003).
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued Emergency Use Authorizations for over 200 different test kits manufactured by various organizations. Each of FDA’s EUA letters relies on 21 U.S.C. § 360bbb- 3(e)(1)(A)(ii)(
I- III)::: stating: “This test is only authorized for the duration of the declaration that circumstances exist justifying the authorization of emergency use of in vitro diagnostics for detection and/or diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2....”
Liability for coercing participation in a medical experiment::: and any injury from it::: may be incalculable. Children’s Health Defense urges U.S. employers::: universities and other institutions to respect and uphold the rights of individuals to refuse EUA tests.
1227 North Peachtree Parkway::: Suite 202. Peachtree City::: GA 30269 www.childrenshe
althdefense.org
column23:
What to do if your school or employer says you must get the COVID vaccine

The Children’s Health Defense legal team has written three legal notifications that anyone faced with a COVID vaccine::: COVID test or mask mandate can use to inform employers and universities that they are violating federal law. You can download the three notifications here.

All of the notifications include this language:

“Federal law::: Title 21 U.S.C. § 360bbb-3(e)(1)(
A)(ii)(I-III) of the Federal Food::: Drug::: and Cosmetic Act::: states the following about products granted emergency authorization usage:

Individuals to whom the product is administered are informed—

(I) that the Secretary has authorized the emergency use of the product;

(II) of the significant known and potential benefits and risks of such use::: and of the extent to which such benefits and risks are unknown; and

(III) of the option to accept or refuse administration of the product::: of the consequences::: if any::: of refusing administration of the product::: and of the alternatives to the product that are available and of their benefits and risks.

Any entity or organization that requires EUA COVID-19 vaccinations::: COVID-19 tests or masks are in violation of federal law::: and will likely face lawsuits if they don’t allow exemptions or alternatives.”

Submitting the notices prepared by Children’s Health Defense is the first step prior to seeking an exemption or taking legal action.

Vaccine exemption laws vary by state. Go to the National Vaccine Information Center to learn more about your state exemptions.

It’s critical to stand against mandates and preserve legally protected::: fundamental human rights on issues related to health freedom. Don’t fall prey to coercion and pressure::: use the resources available to protect your legal rights.

"There may be activities we can make available to those vaccinated::: but not those who decline."

A Protect Purdue press release sent to students just hours later said that students "may enjoy greater amounts of choice as it pertains to activities on campus."

No further information on the activities in question has been released as of 1 p.m. Tuesday.

The decision not to require vaccinations is in place "as of now:::" Daniels said::: but are "subject to change if the facts do."

Protect Purdue will continue to provide free testing to all Boilermakers::: and officials reserve the right to order "targeted testing" in perceived hot spots. Unvaccinated students who don't comply with testing or provide false vaccine documentation will receive "swift and severe disciplinary action::: up to and including expulsion:::" the release reads.

EUA products are by definition experimental and thus require the right to refuse. Under the Nuremberg Code::: the foundation of ethical medicine::: no one may be coerced to participate in a medical experiment. Consent of the individual is “absolutely essential.” A federal court held that the U.S. military could not mandate EUA vaccines to soldiers. Doe #1 v. Rumsfeld::: 297 F.Supp.2d 119 (2003). The court held: "...the United States cannot demand that members of the armed forces also serve as guinea pigs for experimental drugs." Id. at 135. No court has ever upheld a mandate for an EUA vaccine.
The liability for forced participation in a medical experiment::: including injury or death::: may be incalculable. Medical and religious exemptions will be insufficient to overcome the illegality of EUA vaccine mandates. Children’s Health Defense urges U.S. employers::: universities and other institutions to respect and uphold the rights of individuals to refuse EUA COVID-19 vaccines.

column30:
NOTICE FOR EMPLOYERS::: UNIVERSITIES AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS MANDATING COVID-19 TESTS
April 26::: 2021
This serves as notice that the mandate for any individual to be tested against COVID-19 for employment or participation at a university or other institution violates federal law. All COVID-19 tests::: whether polymerase chain reaction (PCR)::: antigen tests or others::: are authorized::: not approved or licensed::: by the federal government; they are Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) only. They merely “may be effective.” Federal law states:
Title 21 U.S.C. § 360bbb-3(e)(1)(
A)(ii)(I-III) of the Federal Food::: Drug::: and Cosmetic Act states:
individuals to whom the product is administered are informed—
(I) that the Secretary has authorized the emergency use of the product;
(II) of the significant known and potential benefits and risks of such use::: and of the extent to which such benefits and risks are unknown; and
(III) of the option to accept or refuse administration of the product::: of the consequences::: if any::: of refusing administration of the product::: and of the alternatives to the product that are available and of their benefits and risks.
EUA products are by definition experimental and thus require the right to refuse. Under the Nuremberg Code::: the foundation of ethical medicine::: no one may be coerced to participate in a medical experiment. Consent of the individual is “absolutely essential.” A federal court held that even the U.S. military could not mandate EUA vaccines to soldiers. Doe #1 v. Rumsfeld::: 297 F.Supp.2d 119 (2003).
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued Emergency Use Authorizations for over 200 different test kits manufactured by various organizations. Each of FDA’s EUA letters relies on 21 U.S.C. § 360bbb- 3(e)(1)(A)(ii)(
I- III)::: stating: “This test is only authorized for the duration of the declaration that circumstances exist justifying the authorization of emergency use of in vitro diagnostics for detection and/or diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2....”
Liability for coercing participation in a medical experiment::: and any injury from it::: may be incalculable. Children’s Health Defense urges U.S. employers::: universities and other institutions to respect and uphold the rights of individuals to refuse EUA tests.
1227 North Peachtree Parkway::: Suite 202. Peachtree City::: GA 30269 www.childrenshe
althdefense.org
column31:
NOTICE FOR EMPLOYERS::: UNIVERSITIES AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS MANDATING COVID-19 MASKS
April 26::: 2021
This serves as notice that the mandate for any individual to wear a mask against COVID-19 for employment or attendance at a university or other institution violates federal law. All COVID-19 masks::: whether surgical::: N95 or other respirators::: are authorized::: not approved or licensed::: by the federal government; they are Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) only. They merely “may be effective.” Federal law states:
Title 21 U.S.C. § 360bbb-3(e)(1)(
A)(ii)(I-III) of the Federal Food::: Drug::: and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) states:
individuals to whom the product is administered are informed—
(I) that the Secretary has authorized the emergency use of the product;
(II) of the significant known and potential benefits and risks of such use::: and of the extent to which such benefits and risks are unknown; and
(III) of the option to accept or refuse administration of the product::: of the consequences::: if any::: of refusing administration of the product::: and of the alternatives to the product that are available and of their benefits and risks.
In a letter dated April 24::: 2020::: the Food and Drug Administration stated that authorized face masks must be labelled accurately and may not be labeled in a way that misrepresents the product’s intended use as “source control to help prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2.” The letter specifies that the labeling “may not state or imply that the product is intended for antimicrobial or antiviral protection or related uses or is for use such as infection prevention or reduction.” Any EUA mandate requiring individuals to wear face masks conflicts with Section 360bbb-3(e)(1)(
A)(ii)(I-III)::: which provides that the person must be informed of the option to refuse to wear the device.
Liability for forced participation in a medical experiment::: including possible injury::: may be incalculable. Children’s Health Defense urges U.S. employers::: universities and other institutions to respect and uphold the rights of individuals to refuse to wear EUA masks.
1227 North Peachtree Parkway::: Suite 202. Peachtree City::: GA 30269 www.childrenshe
althdefense.org
EUA products are by definition experimental and thus require the right to refuse. Under the Nuremberg Code::: the foundation of ethical medicine::: no one may be coerced to participate in a medical experiment. Consent of the individual is “absolutely essential.” A federal court held that even the U.S. military could not mandate EUA vaccines to soldiers. Doe #1 v. Rumsfeld::: 297 F.Supp.2d 119 (2003).

April 23 at 1:25 PM ·

Due to the forecast of inclimate weather::: Race 64 will be postponed until this Sunday::: April 25. In order to keep everyone safe::: we have made the decision to move the date. column1:
“We were on campus today. As we were about halfway through our own walking tour::: with our maps out on full display::: a current student stopped mid-run outside of Armstrong and asked if we needed help. We told him our son was admitted and he proceeded to show us around campus for another 2 hours! I am still in absolute awe! Our son Lucas has officially decided on Purdue. 💛🖤 #BoilerUp” – Sarah::: soon-to-be Purdue parent

Have a favorite #Purdue moment? Share in the comments below! ⬇️
column3: Both of our kids graduated from Purdue and we always enjoyed taking them to their first home football game!! So fun!
column4: My son and I were there just this past Monday and Tuesday::: all the way from CA. Everyone was so friendly and helpful; from the students in the welcome center::: our tour guide::: Jake::: the nuclear engineering student::: who spent 30 minutes answering our questions in the Armstrong building to the lovely girl from Orange County CA who showed us the mock dorm room. We walked ourselves around everywhere::: ate on campus at a few of the eateries::: and explored Lafayette as well. My son is very excited to join as FYE shooting for AAE::: with an emphasis in astronautical. He’s even concluded::: after a virtual meet and greet discussion with the All American Band today to audition for marching band at the end of summer! Feels like home already!!
column5: I have two children there and it is been nothing but wonderful with lots of opportunity. And as much as it was a great tour for you guys::: I am sure this boiler enjoyed showing off how terrific Purdue is! Purdue pride::: ever grateful::: ever true! Best wishes to your family and son. Boilerup!
column6: I'm really disappointed that during my whole Master's that I did not get the opportunity to go to the actual school site (dang Covid). One day::: I will get to the campus! So glad you had a great experience... everything that I experienced as a student would reiterate that this culture is imbedded in Purdue::: which makes me super proud to be a Boilermaker! :)
column7: Loved our trip to Purdue this week! So impressed with the students who were all wearing masks (outside & inside)::: social distancing & looking like they really love being at Purdue!! My daughter fit right in and is excited to start in the fall in the computer science program. #boilerup
column8: When we traveled to the Midwest to do our college tours Purdue wasn't a part of the plan. Actually my daughter was pretty adamant that she would NOT be attending a school with a train as a mascot. However::: we had a little time to burn so I said::: "let's just have a look". After a brief detour and a stroll/drive around campus::: we got back in the car and she said "This is the school I'm going to end up going to. Everyone says when you step foot on the campus that was made for you::: you will know." She knew.
column9: Walking down the engineering mall and watching multiple groups of people smiling::: having fun...the energy on this campus was really infectious! We visited a lot of schools when our son was applying (he's now a sophomore in Honors Engineering) and::: Purdue::: by far::: was the most memorable campus! We love Purdue and it's leadership!
column10: Let’s not forget how great move-in day was during BGR week! Wow!!! That’s the way it should be done at all colleges!!! It’s worth the extra money for that week and move in is flawless::: the traditions are taught too!!! Great week to meet new friends before school starts!
column11: Wait until a group of students meet you at the curb to help your student move in. Moving in all their stuff with kindness and respect for an emotional departure. I was blown away when this happened my daughter’s freshman year. So impressive.
column12: Too many moments to count- BGR::: creating lifelong friendships at Owen and DG::: getting engaged under the bell tower with Bryan Branson... the list goes on. I loved being a campus tour guide too to show my sincere love for my school!
column13: Two current students of alumni parents::: with multiple other family member alumni - we are a Boilermaker family through and through! I beam with pride in our great University every time I hear stories like these! Boiler up!
column14: I love this post Alex. Purdue sounds wonderful. I am so glad you found a University that you love. I am very proud of you Alex. They will love having you as a student. Sending you lots of love always.
column15:
This is the norm::: not the exception. Friendliest campus atmosphere imaginable.❤️

UNLESS we’re playing IU that day. 😂
column16: Proud momma of two Purdue alum. Couldn’t ask for a better experience and education for both of them. Boiler up! My husband and I are both grads of another state university in Indiana::: but so proud to have been able to help our kids achieve their goals.
column17: Congrats to your son. He will love it at Purdue. Great school👍
column18: That's wonderful. We got in a "waitlisted" spot for an official tour recently. So happy to see that Purdue is somewhat open and classrooms had students in them. This became apparently not true at another university.
column19: When I was a prospective student visiting with my mom the amount of students that stopped what they were doing to help us find our way was impressive. I’ll never forget students holding doors for us on that visit either. That sure didn’t happen when I visited IU!
column20: When my niece went to Purdue she felt it was family the minute she stepped campus...her Mother was amazed & asked me what Purdue does to new students to make them feel so quickly bonded. I don't know but it's happened to everyone I know who goes there.
column21: This pick is from our tour pre-Covid. It made me think how few schools would need a sign to tell astronauts where to get lunch.
column22: Texas here; My son did a SURF internship there::: summer of 2017. I attended the presentation he did at the end of the internship and was so impressed by how welcoming and nice everyone was. Beautiful campus too.
column23: I took a campus tour in spring 2019 and knew that day that Purdue was my dream school and I didn’t want to go to college anywhere else. The friendly atmosphere was so inviting and the amount of opportunities available was overwhelming. I can not wait to be a boilermaker this fall as a part of the class of 2025! Boiler up!
column24: On a campus visit for our son two engineering students invited us to eat lunch with them then following lunch went out of their way to walk us to the next building we had to be at! Was by far the nicest campus of people of all our visits. Son is AAE '18.#BoilerUp
column25: We are from NY and my freshman son was admitted to many “out of state” state schools. When visiting Purdue::: we had a one on one meeting with Caitlin Benner::: of Purdue bands and orchestras; and then another with Mr. John Fisher of the math department. The time these selfless people took with my son showed him how small a huge university could feel. It sealed the deal for him and he’s been happy ever since!
column26: Me and my son in matching Purdue masks. We walked around campus on Easter Sunday. He is a junior at Purdue.
column27:
Congrats to your son and YOU!! As a parent of an alumni::: we couldn’t have had a better experience. A Facebook page is usually started for the “class of”! Follow them as it is monitored for a year by someone in the administration.
They help answer questions for you! A life saver for you! Ours is still up. Boilermaker families of the Fall 2013 students. We parents still keep in touch!
column28:
Congratulations
! I'm an old guy (62) with an engineering degree from Purdue. Over 40 years I experienced numerous times employers being impressed with the credentials of a Purdue diploma. From my perspective::: good choice.
column29: I was on campus this afternoon too with my son on a self-guided tour! Didn't need help 'cause I'm a Boilermaker myself 👍 Thank you Jacob B. who gave us a thorough tour of Honors College; that made all the difference.
column30:
That's what Purdue Pride is about...sharing
a wonderful legacy and experience!
column31:
Congratulations
to your son!! My son graduated with a Computer Science Degree last May & it has definitely paid off!! He has a great career thanks to this amazing school!!!!
column32: That’s awesome. Back in the day I was a tour guide showing high school students around campus hoping to convince them that Purdue should be their only choice 🖤💛
column33: My daughter is now an “out of state” senior who will be graduating in May. When we visited::: she knew it was the place for her. Even now::: after 4 years::: this New Yorker is still amazed at how nice everyone is at Purdue. Boiler Up!
column34: I loved every moment of being a campus tour guide at the VIC. Our mission wasn't prospective students but we regularly showed them around and it was exciting to find out what their interests were and tailor the walking tour for them.
column35: We had a very similar experience❤️.... my daughter knew as soon as she walked the campus it was where she belonged ☺️
column36: This has been one of the best threads to read. Teared up a couple times! Purdue definitely felt like home and I remember calling my mom to tell her so several times. 💛🖤 Hoping one of our 3 feels the same when they are making their choice!
column37: I had that experience where a senior::: not wanting us to look silly on our first day::: walked me and my dorm mates around to every building we had class. He showed us shortcuts and places to hang out when we had gaps in our schedule. Saved us from the Freshman mortar board map embarrassment. But it is exactly what I learned to expect from Purdue.
column38: A similar thing happened when my daughter and I were there on a visit 2019. Now my daughter is a sophomore at Purdue and works as a tour guide and she loves it!
column39: We had the same thing happen when I toured campus many years ago. Boilermakers are the best! 💛🖤
column40: “Hoosier by birth::: Boilermaker by the grace of God!!!”
column41:
I am not surprised. Welcome Sarah and congratulations
to your son.
column42: My daughter and I would text each other during basketball game while she was a student. It’s a wonderful memory.
column43: My junior loves it as much as he did his very first day. Sent this pic this afternoon.
column44: I graduated from Purdue in 1988::: and I still miss being there. My favorite four years!
column45: So proud to be a Purdue alumna.❤
column46: I have two::: regarding both Purdue and West Lafayette.
column47: How awesome is that?! Proud to be a boiler!
column48:
Current student here: for students looking to meet with current engineering students::: check out the Purdue Student Engineering Foundation: https://
engineering.purd
ue.edu/PSEF/. On the website you can get into contact with a current student and have your questions answered. We also have students in Armstrong Hall of Engineering from 9-4 during the week!
column49: I had the same experience 44 years ago! Boiler up!
column50: My husband and daughter had a very similar experience when they went to visit the campus! They walked into the Admissions office to ask advice about what to see and the girl offered to walk them around when she got off of work! And after they were done my husband and daughter walked back to the car.. as they passed one of the buildings My daughter heard her name being called and believe it or not .. one of the girls from her high school spotted her high school jacket. Considering we are from New Jersey that was a huge coincidence! needless to say it was fate and she just committed to Purdue. Boiler Up!! 🚂
column51: I did this 30 some years ago...it is easy to “sell” when you love it so much
column52: Marvelous place ! My son graduated a year ago . He loves to visit Purdue on weekends.

President Daniels says at #Purdue we have learned a lot in the last year about alternative ways of getting our jobs done. While some activities clearly need to move back to their previous operating modes – in-person instruction being the most obvious example – many others are candidates for new thinking and new arrangements after the pandemic.

But we will need everyone’s input to get this right. All Purdue faculty and staff are invited to help the university tackle the opportunity.

When women’s sports receive news coverage::: it is “bland” finds a 30-year study from Cheryl Cooky::: a professor of interdisciplinary studies at #PurdueUniversity. Women’s coverage is also lower in technical quality and production value when compared to coverage of men’s sports. Study in partnership with University of Southern California.

https://purdue.university/3d2pVmo

PURDUE.EDU
Overlooking her shot: Women’s sports need an assist as coverage remains the same as 30 years ago
column3: BOILER UP HAMMER DOWN TYLER STRONG CLIZ STRONG
column4:
It’s because women’s sports bring in less money. Last article And piece I saw on the WNBA::: it was a negative income organization that is basically being floated by the NBA.
And although the US Women’s Soccer Team is likely more popular in the US than the men’s::: the issue is internationally
men’s soccer has a larger fan base than the women’s.

It’s a sheer matter of financial sense. Until women’s sports can reach the same level of intensity as men’s::: it’s probably not going to be as profitable::: and therefore::: less coverage.
column5: If this upsets you but biological males competing in women's sports doesn't::: that's a problem.
column6: The government dictated to schools how many sports and scholarships it must offer women. You now want the government to now violate the First Amendment to mandate that the media provide equal coverage?

With Mackey Arena ready for #MarchMadness::: today's #ThrowbackThurdsay highlights its construction.

The Purdue University Arena was dedicated on December 2::: 1967 during a ceremony that included the recognition of 10 former Boilermaker All-Americans. It was renamed Guy J. Mackey Arena in 1971 and::: in 2011::: a major expansion took place. #BoilerUp

Following her days on campus::: she made a significant impact in the health care field in Chicago::: when the majority of working African American women there filled domestic roles.

column1: Amelia Earhart was the first women's career counselor at #PurdueUniversity in 1935 in effort to expand women's education. "Amelia was one of the most famous women in the world:::" Norberg says of Earhart's role. "It was like having a rock star move in." https://purdue.university/2OOj9bu
column3: In the 40s::: when dad bought a 38 Plymouth::: it was great to go to the Purdue airport to watch the planes.
column4: I have very fond memories of living in Earhart Hall and seeing all the artifacts that Purdue had from her life— like her compact and other personal items.
column5: How awesome to have been a student at Purdue during that time!✈️💛🖤
column6: She was amazing. The stories of her going into the drugstore downtown and sitting on the stool and drinking sodas. Dressed in flight jacket::: jodhpur pants::: and boots.
column7: BOILER UP HAMMER DOWN TYLER STRONG CLIZ STRONG
column8: I lived in Duhme Hall where she did!
column9: Amelia Earhart was good friends with Purdue Dean of Women Dorothy Stratton and her office was within the Office of the Dean of Women. Stratton invited Amelia to her home on Sunday evenings for a dinner of waffles. The only thing Stratton knew how to cook. Read more about Amelia in my book The Deans’ Bible published by @PurduePress.
column10: Edward C. Elliott was quite a visionary to bring her in to inspire women students.
column11: wow::: from someone great like her to someone who appoints people to appoint himself as president. how Purdue has fallen.

To celebrate #WomensHistoryMonth::: learn more about Helen Blanche Schleman (1902–1992)::: acknowledged for having fought for women's rights at #Purdue. Noted as an "unapologetic feminist:::" Schleman came to Purdue in 1934 as director of the first women's residence hall. After taking a four-year leave of absence to serve in the Women's Coast Guard Reserve during World War II::: Schleman returned to Purdue in 1947 as Dean of Women. Schleman Hall::: which now houses the Purdue's Student Services department::: is named in her honor. #PurdueUniversity #BoilerUp

*Helen Schleman is pictured second to the left in the first photo.
*Schleman Hall of Student Services is featured in the second photo.

Coach Gene Keady
February 28 at 5:03 PM ·

After an all day drive from Myrtle Beach::: SC (with special thanks to Michael Spencer)::: we arrived in West Lafayette yesterday evening. This morning::: we got Covid tested at Protect Purdue's amazing set up at the Co-Rec. Boilermakers should be extremely proud of the organization of everything put in place on campus and participation by students and staff to make the Protect Purdue mission successful. They completed classes ON campus & online for fall of 2020 and are going for 15 weeks for the spring semester. Take a moment to look the Protect Purdue Dashboard::: it's impressive! https://protect.purdue.edu/dashboard/

column6:
Having spent about a year doing eLearning/
remote learning::: it’s probably easier to pull the trigger to cancel in person classes. When I was on campus back around 1980 (+ or - 2 years) they canceled classes one day::: which I believe was the first time since the beginning of time or thereabouts. 🤪🤣🤠
column7:
We got 1.5 days in 2007 for snow...Tippecan
oe Co was under emergency travel only. I don’t know exact ❄️ amount but I believe >12”. However we still had to walk to class in -30 windchill. 🤷🏻‍♀️ They also had a snow day in 2011.
column8: They didn't cancel classes back in the olden days & women were not allowed on campus in slacks or jeans no matter how deep the snow or low the temperature!
column9: Wimps! Back when I went to Purdue::: we had to walk to class barefoot::: in the snow::: uphill both ways::: five miles and they never cancelled classes. 😆
column10: Anyone remember 1991 Spring semester when there was at least an inch of ice on EVERYTHING?
column11: I graduated in ‘53 and never had a snow day. Women could not wear slacks. I had to walk to the Engineer Campus from trike the hotdog root bear restrant
column12: Once when the wind chill was -60. But::: we all made the game vs IU at Mackey that night!
column13: I don’t miss the ice polishers. Why would a engineering powerhouse of a school think using rotating wire brushes was the best way to clear snow?
column14: I remember walking to class only to find a note on the classroom door cancelling class. I pictured the professor sitting in a leather chair in his study calling it in to some poor teaching assistant. 😂
column15:
I don't recall ever having classes cancelled in the six years I was there from 1973 to 1979. I remember some days we were hopeful::: but our hopes were always dashed :-)

Naive Florida boy that I was::: I bought the warmest jacket I could find for sale in the mall where I lived::: south of Miami. I froze even wearing two sweaters underneath it::: but it took awhile for it to dawn on me that I should shop for proper winter jacket.

I also had a few cartoonish mishaps walking on sheet ice::: going from vertical to horizontal in a split second. One time I landed on my face instead of my back and hit so hard a filling came out and I had to have a gash in my face sewn up at the student hospital. That's what university is for right::: teaching you new things...

I remember days when the snow plow pushed up so much snow that there was a continuous 6 foot high pile on side of the street. You knew your car was under there somewhere::: but you had to dig exploratory holes first to find it::: and then spend an hour shoveling the snow off the top::: away from both sides::: the front::: the back::: and even underneath it in order to get it out.
column16: What?!? We had class in this crap when I was there!
column17: My daughter would rather go to class than have a snow day. Although most of her classes are online due to covid. Going to school during a pandemic::: wearing a mask::: socially distancing::: being randomly tested and not being able to be in groups is mentally challenging for all of them. I think they are pretty resilient.
column18: What? How much snow is there? My dad bought me a special heavy winter weather jacket knowing the weather and they don’t cancel classes when I started.
column19: I was just telling my kids about walking from Harrison Hall to campus for class. COLD days::: wind and not good gear to wear. Brutal. Somehow I don’t remember having a snow day ever.
column20: What? No cancellations in 1988-1992. We got to experience the polished ice from the snow brush machine. 🤣😂
column21: I told my son going to class in weather like this builds character.
column22: The Pizza trucks made it to the dorms just fine the day that classes were cancelled for a day in the mid '80's. 🤣 Yup - went sledding on lunch trays at Slayter that day! I think it was more about profs at IUPUI who couldn't navigate the drifts on I-65 to get to Purdue.
column23: I remember an ice storm when I went there and the wind literally pushed me to class on iced sidewalks😳
column24:

Hey door dash and Amazon are still delivering. So I’m cool.

Off course my heat went out for maybe 24 hours. New house for me. The heat got urned off for some reason. I found the problem the next day and fixed it. This move has been heck.

Once I got to class and after waiting 15-20 minutes for the professor to show only to find out he was stuck and couldn’t get there.

column29: I remember walking to 7:30 am classes in the Field house::: in the snow::: in the dark! I’d walk in tire tracks as sidewalks had not been shoveled!
column30: Class was canceled once in my four years due to an ice storm. I’ll never forget walking to my finals freshman year::: snow up to my knees and a windchill of -14 degrees. Not to mention the bitterly cold nights as a student security patroller. It was always beautiful though.

column6:
In honor of Black History Month...thinkin
g of all the children in the Congo.
Sweat runs from my black
Skin. I dig for Coltan today.
I’m seven and know how to
Wash the Coltan and Cobalt
In the dirty Congo river::: so mama
Can have coffee::: rice and flour;
So my baby sister can have goat
Milk::: and my grandmama will
Have meat from the Tutsi farms.
I see friends running to school
In their white shirts and blue pants.
They can read and write::: but I dig
Cobalt today. Washing my hands
And feet in the muddy water::: I see
My knuckles and hands are white
With calluses::: but I make two
Dollars if I dig enough coltan.
I’ll dig for more coltan today.
Far away they tell us that some
Children my age have cell phones
In their back pockets. They must
Have my coltan to make those
Phones they carry to their schools
Where they learn to read and write.
Where they play soccer late and
Dress in white shirts and blue pants.
So I’ll dig for more coltan today.

column27: Winnie's Saga::: Fleeing the Congolese War::: is a true story of a woman who flees from the Congo during the aftermath of the Rwandan Genocide. She and her two young daughters escape the clashing armies from the Congo and Rwanda and end up in Kenya for 12 years as refugees. They eventually come to Indianapolis::: Indiana where the girls attend high school::: and go on to college. Today the whole family are US citizens. This is an amazing story of perseverance and determination. A great read for high school and college students who are interested in the sweeping history of Africa and the plight of refugees who escape violence. Available on Amazon.

column1:
It’s all about the details in #Purdue Memorial Union. 🖤💛 The historical design holds many meanings::: including the stained glass windows representing the mix of students of all races and creeds welcome within its walls. #FlashbackFriday to 1977. Purdue Memorial Union

Learn more about the architecture: https://purdue.university/3ah04Hf
column3: Thanks for posting it's been years since I've been there. Lots of great memories of working on campus and Don as a student. We !lived in married student housing::: which I heard was torn down.
column4: I love sitting here::: on the other side there’s a fireplace and I’ve seen it going once. Another time someone was playing the piano. You never know what gem this area will offer up.
column5: The sweet shop ::: good friends ::: hamburgers and fries and studying way back in 1977 1978 . It was so precious to spend time there . They had dances there . We used to watch Tv there in between classes . Thanks 🙏 loved it .Boiler up ❤️❤️❤️🌹
column6: One of my favorite places to study for finals. I would find a vacant::: majestic lounge area that would transport me to a different realm. It was calming::: and I felt able to concentrate. Such a treasure!
column7: A fun place to hang out as a preteen/teen. Bowling::: pool::: soft pretzels at the Sweet Shop. The tunnels::: the map. The Christmas Tree.
column8: Awesome to hear the history of this beautiful building! Boiler UP!!

column10: the cafeteria downstairs was pretty good.
column11: There was a reflecting pond while I was there::: 1980-1989.
column12:
I had a look at the Wikipedia page for the Purdue Memorial Union. I zoomed in on the stained glass windows::: to the point that I could read the texts along the top and bottom.

As best I can make out::: it says...
"Our poor spirit is so weak it is only through the use of materials that it can rise to the truth."

Around the figures are references to "Sister Water"::: "Brother Wind"::: "Brother Fire"::: "Brother Earth".

Some of the figures are cradling things in their arms like Mary might be cradling Jesus in a medieval picture::: except in this case what I see cradled are a train::: a plane::: and a tank::: among other things::: some of which I didn't immediately recognize. This is in keeping with the union being a war memorial.

At the bottom is:
"In memory of James H. Smart President of the University 1883 - 1900. Presented to the University by the Class of 1940."

The figures are in the same style as craftsmen::: knights or saints that you might find in stained glass windows in medieval cathedrals.

So here is my question: how did you come up with this interpretation?


>> "The historical design holds many meanings::: including the stained glass windows representing the mix of students of all races and creeds welcome within its walls."

I have no objection to rededicating it as such::: but I find the notion doubtful that in the 1930's a rainbow coalition existed and had that in mind when the stained glass was designed.

I don't see any people of color represented in it::: nor any indication of creeds or religions::: apart from the style itself having been copied from Christian cathedrals.

column1:
Hail Purdue! The Boilermaker family thanks David and Bonnie Brunner for their $10 million leadership commitment to the new veterinary hospital. The David and Bonnie Brunner Purdue Veterinary Medical Hospital Complex is slated to open by spring 2022. The 162:::500-square-foot complex will feature three facilities—a small animal hospital::: an equine hospital::: and a farm animal hospital—located just east of the existing Lynn Hall of Veterinary Medicine. In addition to treating animals::: the complex will serve as a catalyst for interdisciplinary research::: including cancer drug discovery and the development of treatments for paralysis. To learn more::: visit https://purdue.university/3oUcQz8. #EverGratefulEverTrue

Purdue University College of Veterinary Medicine & Veterinary Hospital

column4:
I’m anxious to see the tv series (tho I may have to get the book now). I read his “Rising Tide” book in two sittings. A story well told meshing the tale of Bear’s coach-player relationship with Joe Namath and Bryant’s realization that it was time to break the Dixie barrier that had for so long kept black athletes off rosters in southern universities.
Robert’s has written quite an array of sports history books. Purdue is fortunate to have him on board - not just for his literary accomplishments
but for his classroom skills.

column1: In the fall of 1935::: Amelia Earhart joined the faculty of #PurdueUniversity::: serving as a counselor in the study of careers for women and an adviser in aeronautics. She soon began planning a world flight at the equator with her Lockheed Electra airplane::: purchased with funds from the Purdue Research Foundation. #ThrowbackThursday

column5: Did you know there is a Purdue ID student who is a descendant cousin of Amelia? Who knew!!!

According the CDC::: 625 young people have died from "Covid" related causes. This is terrible::: but how terrible? 625 souls out of 50:::000:::000 young people below the age of 25 is a survival rate of 99.99875%. In other words::: those age 16-19 are 4 times more likely to die in a car crash than from Covid::: FOUR TIMES. 2333 in that age group of just 8.5 million lost their lives in car wrecks. Let's address issues that really impact our lives year in and year out. https://
www.cdc.gov/
nchs/nvss/vsrr/
covid_weekly/
index.htm#AgeAnd
Sex

column5: I sit here and read these comments and am disappointed. At the same time it is the right of everyone in this great country to have different opinions and to be able to voice those. That is what my Dad fought for and I’m sure many who have made these comments have done the same. As I look at former President’s sitting together::: some I voted for others I did not::: I always respected the office. Did I vote for President Trump::: no but that was my right as it was yours to vote how you wanted to. As one of the speakers said::: every four years their are happy and sad people but we need to come together. This country faces many challenges as it has in the past and we have always rallied together to beat them. In the past::: we have respected others opinions and we need to go back to that. Not name calling::: cursing::: etc but listening and agreeing to disagree. This is what this country was built on.

(Prerequisite for graduation) I also played basketball on the Woman’s Intercollegiate Club team. We played a couple of games there and I remember my parents watching from the track above. If walls could talk::: I think there would be great stories. Am pleased it wasn’t torn down and replaced but refurbished and put to good use! It will always be the Memorial Gym to me!
column7: I hated that swimming pool. It was only 20 yards long::: and as a previous competitive swimmer::: I knew instinctively how many strokes in a lap (of a normal 25 yard pool). I crashed into the wall more times than I care to remember::: while mindlessly swimming laps.
column8: Very familiar with this building as the Women's Gym! Used to have to "run" after class to get to the dining hall at my dorm before the doors for dinner closed.

Did you know that Purdue's first president was Richard Owen::: a Civil War veteran who was integral to the University's creation? #Purdue
column3: And the only person with memorial busts at Purdue::: IU and in the Indiana StateHouse.
column4: His father was a Welsh textile manufacturer::: philanthropist and social reformer::: was one founder of utopian socialism and the cooperative movement. He is known for efforts to improve factory working conditions for his workers and promote experimental socialistic communities. President Owen would try to incorporate these ideas as our 1st President::: seeking better student living conditions and student self rule. You just have to love the fact that Purdue's 1st president was a true progressive thinker!
