column22: It's great that tuition has frozen::: but Mitch's salary sure hasn't. The tuition freeze is just a PR move. Many colleges that aren't Engineering and Agriculture are seeing cuts that don't give them the resources to fairly pay their graduate students and adjuncts::: student services are overstretched (try to get yourself an appointment at CAPS!)::: and there aren't enough class seats or dorm rooms for all the extra students being admitted because increasing enrollment is one of Mitch's bonus items. I'm glad that tuition freezes make a college education accessible for a lot of families::: but anyone who takes a second to look a little closer recognizes it's all smoke and mirrors.

skip to end for siberian sea methane 2018 readings 100+times normal) - Climate State https:// youtu.be/ TyqrB2Rgy08  http:// climatestate.com /2020/09/04/ extreme-methane- hydrate-dissoci ation-discovere d-near-brazil-c oast/ A joint research team from Brazil and France::: spearheaded by professor Marcelo Ketzer and his colleagues from the Linnaeus University uncovered methane gas leakage from gas hydrate dissociation in the Southern Hemisphere for the first time.  https:// www.ecowatch.com / siberia-sea-boil ing-methane-264 0900862.html or just use a bucket today! and https:// edition.cnn.com/ 2019/10/12/us/ arctic-methane-g as-flare-trnd/ index.html (CNN)Russian scientists studying Arctic waters found the most powerful ever methane jets shooting up from the seabed to the water's surface::: they said Friday.  Igor Semiletov::: the chief scientist aboard a vessel carrying 65 scientists on a 40-day research voyage::: told CNN via satellite phone that he found amounts of methane in the air over the East Siberian Sea up to nine times the global average. Methane is a powerful greenhouse gas::: with a significantly greater global warming potential than carbon dioxide::: according to NASA. The methane emissions in the Arctic::: fueled by the melting of permafrost on the sea floor::: are one driver of climate change::: NASA said. The emissions are presenting a growing risk. Methane levels Semiletov's team found in the air above the seawater were "extremely high:::" he said. “Nobody has detected these concentrations. ”  'Sleeping giant' Arctic methane deposits starting to release::: scientists find  https:// www.theguardian. com/science/ 2020/oct/27/ sleeping-giant-a rctic-methane-d eposits-startin g-to-release-sc ientists-find Exclusive: expedition discovers new source of greenhouse gas off East Siberian coast has been triggered  Levels of overlooked greenhouse gas are up to 45 times higher in fields that are only flooded intermittently https:// www.independent. co.uk/ environment/ rice-farming-cli mate-change-glo bal-warming-ind ia-nitrous-oxid e-methane-a8531 401.html  Reuters exclusively reported that the European Union’s long-awaited plan to curb emissions of the potent greenhouse gas methane will not impose binding standards on natural gas sold in the bloc https:// www.reutersagenc y.com/en/ reuters-best/ reuters-exclusiv ely-reports-dra ft-eu-methane-s trategy-shies-a way-from-bindin g-emissions-sta ndards/  Alberta Tar sands Producing 62 Million tons of CO2 per year 2015 https:// youtu.be/ PD7Yfrwx-OQ and Growing fast  Siberian forest::: Tundra::: Permafrost::: actually on fire BBC Apocalypse coverage https:// www.youtube.com/ watch?v=neFfTbqi uoY&list=PLSE68 JfXR_1lT_v0Ju0r 2wt3NZXSR5DxC&i ndex=13 And part of the same BBC report: Permafrost melting away https:// www.youtube.com/ watch?v=YAnTwXYg 2Ic&list=PLSE68 JfXR_1lT_v0Ju0r 2wt3NZXSR5DxC&i ndex=16 I like that even though he is the BBC’s Moscow Political correspondent; he uses words like Apocalypse and Armageddon. He believes. He sees the Truth.  Note CarbonBrief: By the end of 2019::: the concentration of methane in the atmosphere reached around 1875 parts per billion (ppb)::: the researchers say – more than two-and-a-half times pre-industrial levels. Arctic conditions for Methane release become more favorable  Bubbles of methane gas frozen into clear ice in Baikal Lake in Siberia

No matter the day of the week and no matter whether you're on or off campus::: don't let your mask down to help #ProtectPurdue.

For more than 150 years::: the #Purdue community has been connected like no other. As we protect ourselves::: others and our Purdue campus from COVID-19::: we maintain hope that we can make more memories like these in the near future. #INThisTogether #BoilerUp #TheNextGiantLeap

column4: We were there this weekend visiting our daughter. She is depressed and miserable. 1/2 classes in person 1/2 on line. She can’t do any of her activities or clubs she participated in last year as they were cancelled due to Covid. It’s very stressful. The kids worry about getting sick. For the 3 days we were there we hardly saw kids out the campus was dead. And we just received an email saying next semester you have to be on campus no matter what even if all of your classes are all on line. No more being remote and online. This Is bullshit. It is all about the money you cannot ask students to live on campus tell them no spring break and have them take their classes on line and stay in their dorm rooms. If your goin to do that Purdue then make all the professors teach their classes in person! And have all classes in person. I am a Purdue grad myself very disappointed with purdue
column5: Poor Kids are miserable at School.
column7: Thank you Mitch Daniels and Purdue students for doing such a great job
column8: Thank you Mitch Daniels for keeping us open and going. Proud of Purdue. Proud to have been a student. Proud to be employee.
column9: You can argue about this all you want::: but the bottom line is hospital beds at IU Health Arnett are almost full and if things don’t improve more restrictions will be coming. Purdue is not an island. What goes on there affects the rest of Tippecanoe County. Even if our young::: healthy students experience only mild symptoms that won’t be true for everyone. I’m not sure why that seems to be such a difficult concept for some.
column10: Another great message from a great leader.
column11: If Mitch cared at all about our mental health::: then we wouldn't need a "significant change" to do all online classes. A pandemic would be enough. This semester wouldn't be as disorganized as it has been. The Breakfast Club situation should not have been allowed. Football would not be happening if anyone cared about the safety of the athletes or their families. We would have had even ONE day of break::: but we really don't. Because the one we were given is optional::: so we have been going at this non-stop until Thanksgiving gets here. Weekends don't count anymore::: because those are also taken up by work. He can pretend all he wants that he cares::: but he is doing this for the money. If he had any sympathy for us::: he wouldn't keep spreading the GRIT gospel about how Purdue students can withstand anything. It's a pathetic excuse to turn a blind eye to the fact that many students have become depressed due to all the work we have thrown at us during a global crisis.

column8: This reminded me of other historical things at Purdue. The Old Water Pump. I was a tour guide 37 years ago working for the Greater Lafayette Convention & Tourism bureau and met my husband of 35 years (anniversary next week) when he was a charter bus driver from Indianapolis. The water pump has a history of "romance" in that couples would agree to meet at the pump at certain times during the night when it was allowed to be out if you needed water. I wondered if it still worked when I shared this with the tour group and Bill knew that was my signal I was available. :) Did not intend to ramble::: but this brought the memory to mind when I saw it.  https:// www.purdue.edu/ newsroom/ purduetoday/ didyouknow/2014/ Q4/ did-you-know-the -old-pump-.html

column1: #Repost @boilerambassadors with @get_repost ・・・ Today’s #SmallStepsWithStudents in healthcare feature is Isabella Hannigan from @boilerfootball 🏈🏈🏈  What is your healthcare role?: Right now I’m an athletic trainer with the football team so I do a lot of their treatments before and after practice.  How was your role impacted by COVID-19? Did you work during the pandemic/lockdown?: During covid I wasn’t able to work with any teams but I did work as a pharmacy tech which was really interesting during the covid era. We did curbside pickup and curbside vaccines which was definitely interesting.  What is your favorite health tip to give to students?: My favorite health tip would be focus on wellbeing as a whole::: and not just one aspect.  What is your favorite part of being back on campus?: My favorite part about being on campus is meeting new people and learning different perspectives::: whether in person or virtually.  #LetsPlayFootball #PurdueUniversity #BoilerUp

Please do not underestimate this issue!

Meet Christelle Altidor! The #ProtectPurdue Student Ambassador of the week.  🖤 Year in School: Sophomore  💛 Major: Nursing Purdue School of Nursing  🖤 Why did you become an Ambassador? As an international student::: I spend more time on campus than at home thus Purdue as become a second home for me. When I learned that campus would reopen for in-person instruction::: I was excited and wanted to help keep our community safe in order to remain on campus. The ambassador program gave me the opportunity to be involved in helping so many students including myself stay on a campus that they consider their home.  💛 What is your favorite socially distanced activity now that the semester has begun? Since the semester started::: I have really enjoyed movie nights whether it’s at Ross- Ade::: Fowler or at my place. I find that it is a great way to socialize::: catch up with friends and get a break from homework.

column4: I remember the day as if it were yesterday. Waking up in my room in the Wiley tunnel::: going to the bathroom to get ready before Tuesday morning classes::: and a hallmate saying something happened in NY. Watching the second plane hit. Getting the first reports of something happening at the Pentagon before needing to hurry to my first class of the day. Walking to class and seeing all the planes making a beeline back to the airfield. Classes being a blur. Walking through the fall job fair and seeing all the the tables for govt agencies empty. Running into a friend at the job fair later who told me that both towers fell and my somehow properly calling it an operation by AQ/OBL. Sitting in the Union lounge between classes watching the news. Walking back to Wiley and hearing the exact same broadcast coming out of every open window. Thinking everything had changed. And it had.

column1: Dr. Al G. Wright's contributions to #PurdueUniversity will be remembered for years to come. Thank you for all the musical memories. 🖤💛  Purdue Bands & Orchestras September 5::: 2020 at 7:33 PM ·  It is with heavy heart that we share with you tonight::: Dr. Al G. Wright passed away at his home in West Lafayette at the age of 104. Dr. Wright served as Director for Purdue Bands & Orchestras from 1954 to 1981. He remained one of our biggest supporters alongside his wife::: Gladys::: throughout his lifetime. Nearly half of our long history is marked by his relentless leadership and their generosity. We look forward to celebrating his wonderful legacy over the weeks to come.  Please keep Gladys and the entire Wright family in your thoughts and prayers as they grieve the loss of our Director of Bands Emeritus::: Dr. Al G. Wright.

African forest elephants::: highly sociable animals::: travel in small family groups to meet others at these muddy water sources::: which are full of rich minerals they can’t find in the forests. By clearing routes to these destinations::: elephants have created a very complex network of roads that residents::: tourists::: scientists and loggers still use today. “Think of elephants as engineers of the forests:::” said Melissa J. Remis::: professor and head of anthropology at Purdue University::: who is best known for her work in ecology and behavior of western gorillas and their ecosystems.  PURDUE.EDU Following African elephant trails to approach conservation differently

column9: For all of you who are bitching about "Protect Purdue"; I'm sure Tony Butkovich would have liked staying on campus with whatever rules may have been in place at the time::: instead of heading to Paris Island::: then later to Okinawa where he was KIA. Maybe today's youth need to face real life::: which says that there are no guarantees in life ( I know::: the old death and taxes idea )::: but what happens if they have to have a year. or so::: NOT at university. My nephew finished a 5-year hitch in the Marine Corps::: and literally enrolled in college last year. I call him "Marine" because he earned the title ! Maybe a hitch in the military would teach the youth of today that they don't need "safe places" on a college campus::: but that "learning::: oft for the sake of learning" is what it's all about-\-\-then being prepared for a career based on a serious course of study and the actual education they achieved.
